intro: Sabatia macrophylla var. recurvans, commonly known as the recurved sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils along coastal dunes and maritime bluffs. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often recurved at the tips, giving the species its varietal name. It blooms from late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
